One example is accismus.impl.Configuration which still uses zookeeper APIs directly

I do have a bunch of work for this in a local branch. There were a couple wonky places where the exception chains made it not so straight forward. Needless to say, I don't think it'll take too long to complete.

Yes.  I created an account.  My username is mikewalch.

One side affect of this is that an oracle could still be in a bad state when it goes to requeue and this could be a very hard state to troubleshoot and manage. Keith's idea for #76 will force the Oracle to halt the VM when it loses leadership so that YARN can reschedule an Oracle somewhere else. This will be  a much more maintainable solution.

The information we need to provide in the JIRA ticket:

groupID, project url, scm url, username(s), project summary

GroupId=io.fluo
ProjectURL=http://fluo.io
SCMUrl=https://github.com/fluo-io/
Usernames=cjnolet, mikewalch, etc...
Project Summary=Fluo is an implementation of Google's Percolator written for Apache Accumulo.

Closing this issue as it's easier to just re-instantiate the thrift OracleService.Client class.

Made some updates- specifically to reach out to the previous leader and ask it if it still thinks it's the leader. It should halt now when leadership is lost so that we can have YARN spin up a new one somewhere else.
I was going to recommend this when you sent your script out. +1

in SnapshotScanner.getNext() I think the following code block should go away.  If another thread is alive (still has ephemeral node) then this code may try to roll forward a running transaction.  That should be harmless, but its unnecessary work.     

``` java
if (firstSeen == -1) { ...}
```
looks good, this is ready to merge after you squash
commits are now squashed into one
@keith-turner can review the Bytes classes before I go through the code change ByteSequence to Bytes
The fix for the bug in Curator is going to be 2.6.1. I think this patch should be ready for review. Illput in a ticket to update curator to 2.6.1 when it is released.

could possibly add a timeout to the test and change 

``` java
  Assert.assertEquals(1, getNumOpen())
```

to 

``` java
  while( getNumOpen() != 1){Thread.sleep(50);}
```

this way the test would get past the while loop as soon as possible, or it would timeout
I was encountering this problem last night and i actually increased the amount of sleep time from 1 second to 4 seconds in one of my pull requests because it appeared to stop when I did.

I can imagine, as a user, having services that use Fluo directly but having a hard time adjusting to the same class name with different packages. Would it make sense to call this FluoRange or something that could alleviate confusion between the two?

I can go either way on this.  This will become an issue if you users need
to use both Fluo's and Accumulo's Range in the same class.  Otherwise, I
don't think it's a big deal.

I certainly imagine using both together. From my standpoint, and from comments of many others on the Accumulo mailing list, people are going to want to incrementally delete/add mutations to other indexes in other tables in their observers. I would want to ingest with Fluo and query with the Accumulo api (using my own custom iterators for intersections and whatnot)

Not I think Accumullo will seek to the next col fam if it scans a bit and does not find it.  Just not sure it does this for col quals.

@mikewalch it's not required that we put our domain as the project url. It would be nice to have it forwarded but for now I could just put the link to github and we could change it later.
I don't think it does either and it's something i've been curious about for awhile. Is it even possible, given the current format of the rfile, to seek directly to a column qualifier?

Is there a specific requirement for it to be multiple workers? Would we save anything by having a single worker process handling notifications for a couple different tables? (I ask this without having formally looked at the API but it seems like a reasonable enough question).
Would almost be neat to use the JSR BeanShell spec to accomplish this. That way we could natively support a bunch of different languages.

It doesn't look like anything was done to alleviate concerns about conflicting class names in the Fluo API. The reason I'm bringing this up now is because it's going to be much harder to rename in the future.

How about using Span for the class name?  While i like FluoRange, it's
weird to include Fluo in data type.  I would rather keep it short.

could also have methods like :

``` java
  Bytes getFamily()
   Bytes getQualifier()
   Bytes getValue()
```

Some advantages of running a Fluo instance per table :
- Isolation:  One of the observers for two unrelated tables can not impeded each other.  It also makes it easier to allocate resources per table.  
- Easier resource allocation : If a high priority table is falling behind, add more workers just for that table using YARN.

The only advantage I can think of for making a singler worker process multiple tables, is the possibility of getting higher utilization on the cluster.   The worker would always keep its threads busy with whatever table had work.  Where in the case of a worker process per table, it may be that some of the worker processes on a node have many idle threads and some are utilizing all threads.   In the case of worker per table, we could possibly try to achieve high utilization by starting and stopping worker processes as needed.  Would need a centralized process to monitor and make these decisions.
I am inclined to remove this from the 1.0.0 feature list in favor if using YARN to allocate resource, instead of fluo trying to do itself.
I'm fine with the name Span. FluoRange was just a recommendation off the top of my head.

This issue is kinda tricky and not covered in paper.  Posting a design of this issue for review.   Once we feel the design is sound, we can move on to implementation.

Definitions :
- Transactor : a process executing transaction.
- IDLE       : transactor not currently executing any transactions
- BUSY       : transactor currently executing transactions
- TLTNODE    : transactor logical time node, each transactor will have an emphemeral node in zookeeper that tracks the oldes logical start time for transactions is currently executing  
- START_TS   : a transactions logical start timestamp from oracle
- TR[0-9]    : an instance of a transactor
- GC[0-9]    : an instance of a garbage collection iterator

Transactor rules
- IDLE -> BUSY : must place TLNODE in zookeeper before executing any transactions
- BUSY -> IDLE : delete TLTNODE
- while BUSY : periodically update TLNODE with minimum START_TS from all transactions running.  Do not want to do this to frequently, it would put a lot of write pressure on ZK.

Garbage collection iterator rules
- in init() select a min timestamp, gciter will not remove anything newer than this while it runs.
- when selecting timestamp, choose minimum from TLNODEs in zookeeper.  If no TLNODES in zk, grab timestamp from oracle.
- when garbage collecting, leave at least one entry less than the minimum time selecting in init().  

Example scenario of concurrent transactor and gc iters running
1. start, set of TLNODEs in ZK is empty
2. GC1 starts executing and grabs min time of 6 (from oracle.)
3. TR1 transations from IDLE to BUSY
4. TR1 sets its TLTNODE to 8 (allocated from oracle) before executing any transactions
5. TR1 starts executing a transaction with a START_TS of 11
6. TR1 starts executing another transaction with a START_TS of 15
7. GC2 starts executing and selects a minimum timestamp of 8.
8. GC1 encounters a row/column with versions at times 3,5,7,9.   It drops version 3
9. GC2 encounters a row/column with versions at times 3,5,7,9.   It drops versions 3 and 5
10. TR1 updates its TLNODE to 11
11. GC3 starts executing and selects a minimum timestamp of 11.
12. GC3 encounters a row/column with versions at times 3,5,7,9,15.   It drops versions 3,5, and 7
13. TR1 finishes executing both transactions
14. TR1 deletes its TLNODE after being idle for a bit

Currently transactions detect reading data past the point of garbage collection. This should be left as a sanity check.  Hopefully should not run into this case after this change.

Specifically, the gpg plugin needs to be added. We should probably have a release profile for this- otherwise it'll run everytime someone builds (requiring that user to have a gpg key and agent running).

On Fri, Aug 1, 2014 at 5:15 PM, Keith Turner notifications@github.com
wrote:

> oopppss, pressed 'close and comment' instead of comment
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/fluo-io/fluo/pull/110#issuecomment-50935664.

Thought of a problem with the design mentioned.
1. GC5 looks in ZK and sees no TLNODEs
2. TR7 transations from IDLE to BUSY
3. TR7 set its TLTNODE to 18 (allocated from oracle)
4. TR7 starts executing a transaction with a START_TS of 21
5. GC5 grabs min time of 25 (from oracle.)
6. GC5 encounters row/column RC1 with versions at times 3,22.   It drops versions 3
7. TR7 transaction w/ START_TS of 21 reads RC1 and gets a stale scan exception

I think garbage collection init() needs to always do the following.  The inital design called for optionally getting an oracle timestamp, if the TLTNODEs in zk were empty.  Thats what caused the problem above.
1. long otime = <allocate timestamp from oracle>
2. list<long> zktimes = <get list of TLTNODEs from ZK>
3. gcMinTime =  min(otime, zktimes)

This tweak improves things, even for the hairy situation below.
1. TR8 transations from IDLE to BUSY
2. TR8 gets time 13 from oracle to set for its TLTNODE, but does not set it
3. GC9 grabs min time of 15 (from oracle.)
4. GC9 looks in ZK and sees no TLNODEs, so uses min time of 15
5. TR8 set its TLTNODE to 13
6. TR8 starts executing a transaction with a START_TS of 21 ()
7. GC9 encounters row/column RC1 with versions at times 3,22.   It drops nothing

Seems like the following can be asserted.
- All GC starting before step 6 will have a time stamp < 21 (this protects the transaction from GC that started immediately before the transaction)
- All GC starting after step 5 will have a time stamp <= 13 (this protects the transaction from GC that started after the transaction started)
Changes made based on @keith-turner's suggestion of using try-with-resources with the CuratorFramework. #112 created for making sure worker is sharing only 1 zookeeper connection.
Would probably be better to do this later in the dev cycle of 1.0 when the API stabilizes.
Also thinking for 1.0.0, it would be best to create the simplest thing thats useful.  Its easier to add complexity later if needed, rather than remove something that was not needed.

Definitely need something to test performance.   The primary purpose of #24 was to test for correctness at scale.  The google paper mentioned a test they wrote for clustering random documents with three random keys.  I think the keys were random ints mod 10^9.   I never was exactly sure what that test did.

I'm good with merging this after the commits are squashed.

Fixed the wording
may want to consider using CharSequence in API instead of String.  String implements CharSequence

I like the idea of having one Properties class.  We could call it FluoProperties and it would correspond to one config file.  While most properties would have defaults, we could have methods in FluoProperties to check if certain required properties are set when running a client, worker, oracle, etc.  This would insure that users set the required properties when necessary.
Related to issue #73

was working on making phrasecount example work again, and ran into the following w/ props which seemed redundant.

`FluoFactory.newAdmin(props).initialize(props)`

Updated based on feedback from Mike and Keith
Updated based on feedback from @keith-turner
Updated based on feedback. 'release' profile split into 'sign' and 'full' profiles so javadocs and source jars can be built without the need to sign the artifacts.
I was thinking about this too. Probably a good idea to put it in the "full" profile

This seems similar to a sliding window problem. I was thinking about this a little today. Perhaps a time ordered cache could be used to keep the timestamps of the last n times the Oracle had to reach out Zookeeper. Some function based on the difference between the first and last item in the cache could help determine the final batch size.
It looks like when the batch scanner is created, the authorizations used for the scan are pulled out of the environment. Should they get pulled from somewhere else?

Authorizations are not passed anywhere right now.  I was thinking auths could be configuration.  So a worker process could be configured to run w/ a certain set of auths.   A FluoClient could be configured to use a certain set of auths.  Need to create an issue for this, I'll do that if there is not one.

This issue address the problem of when a specific column vis is requested.  If the column cf=a,cq=9,cv=S  is requested then currently I think all column vis would be returned instead of just S.

Could have a target maximum frequency (possibly configurable), like I don't want the oracle to hit zookeeper more than twice a second.   The system would adjust its allocations to try to avoid exceeding this frequency.  Its probably ok if it exceeds the max freq for a short period, just do not want to exceed it for long periods of time.    If its below the max frequency it could allocate some minimum # of timestamps.
Opened #142.  Realized that was needed while reviewing this.
